chapter.title: Login Screen
chapter.para: The Login Screen is what you see when your system has started up. It allows you to log into your system. To make you feel even more at home you may change the appearance of that login dialog.

When you select the Login Screen menu item, you are prompted for your password. Remember, there is no administrator password. If you need special privileges to change system-wide settings and you get asked for a password - then it is always your own password.

Once the Login Screen Setup window appears you will see different tabs on the top. You can see that there is a difference between the Standard Greeter and the Graphical Greeter. Basically the Standard Greeter is a simple login window which does not look very fancy. It's hardly used. The Graphical Greeter instead is the login dialog that Ubuntu uses by default. It can have background images and there are a large number of so called themes that allow you to customise the look.
Let us go through the tabs one by one:

sect1.title: General
sect1.para: In the first section you can choose the type of greeter (standard or graphical) for local or remote sessions. Local means that you are sitting at the PC and want to login. In addition, you can allow other people to access your workstation from remote. A remote session means that all data that is usually displayed on your screen needs to be sent through the network. So it is advised to use the Standard Greeter which is more lightweight and therefore faster because it contains less fanciness.
Unless you are living in a country that divides the day into a.m. and p.m. you are advised to set the always use 24 hour clock format option.

The welcome string is the text that will be displayed on the login screen when you use the standard greeter. Equally the remote welcome string will be printed on the screen when you are logging in from other workstations. It will not be shown if you use the graphical greeter.

Another nice but also dangerous feature is the automatic login. This will make the selected user to be logged in automatically. So you will hardly see the login screen but will be forwarded directly to the Gnome desktop. Please keep in mind that the login screen is for your own security and prevents that someone powers on your workstation and plays with your data. Even if you are usually the only person that uses your system you better do not use this feature.

sect1.title: Standard Greeter
sect1.para: As explained above the standard greeter is a more fanciless way to log into your system. The default is still the graphical greeter for local logins. If you chose to use the standard greeter you can customize the look and feel here. In the logo part on the left you can click on Browse and choose another image to be displayed on the login screen.
On the bottom left there is a checkbox to enable the face browser. If properly configured it will display a photo for every user that can log into your system instead of just the user names.

On the right side you can choose how you want the background to look. You may select no background, just a single color or a selectable image (which may be stretched or shrunk if it does not exactly match the screen size).
